articles.headline: In Florida, Addicts Find an Oasis of Sobriety
articles.snippet: Delray Beach is the epicenter of the country’s largest and most vibrant recovery community.
articles.abstract: Delray Beach is the epicenter of the country’s largest and most vibrant recovery community.
articles.lead_paragraph: DELRAY BEACH, Fla. — Whitney Tower, 56, a scion of the Whitney, Vanderbilt and Drexel fortunes, squandered his trust fund and sold family treasures to support a $1,000-a-day heroin habit before landing in a tough-love facility near here seven years ago and never leaving. “If I went back to New York I’d be dead in two weeks,” he said.

articles.headline: Militants Gain Despite Decree by Musharraf
articles.snippet: Militants in Pakistan’s tribal areas have captured more territory inside settled areas despite an emergency decree.
articles.abstract: Militants in Pakistan’s tribal areas have captured more territory inside settled areas despite an emergency decree.
articles.lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Nov. 15 — Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the Pakistani president, says he instituted emergency rule for the extra powers it would give him to push back the militants who have carved out a mini-state in Pakistan’s tribal areas.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez and Ismail Khan

articles.headline: Betting an Estate on Inhaled Insulin
articles.snippet: Alfred E. Mann is betting nearly $1 billion of his own money that he can succeed where Pfizer failed.
articles.abstract: Alfred E. Mann is betting nearly $1 billion of his own money that he can succeed where Pfizer failed.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 15 — Pfizer, the world’s biggest drug company, flopped miserably with a seemingly can’t-miss idea. But Alfred E. Mann is so certain he can succeed that he is betting nearly $1 billion of his own money on the effort.

articles.headline: Court Rejects Fuel Standards on Trucks
articles.snippet: A federal appeals court said that new fuel-economy standards for light trucks, including S.U.V.’s, didn’t thoroughly assess the impact of greenhouse gases.
articles.abstract: A federal appeals court said that new fuel-economy standards for light trucks, including S.U.V.’s, didn’t thoroughly assess the impact of greenhouse gases.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 15 — A federal appeals court here rejected the Bush administration’s year-old fuel-economy standards for light trucks and sport utility vehicles on Thursday, saying that they were not tough enough because regulators had failed to thoroughly assess the economic impact of tailpipe emissions that contribute to climate change.
articles.byline: By Felicity Barringer and Micheline Maynard

articles.headline: Washington Scrutinizes Nursing Homes
articles.snippet: Congressional hearings were prompted in part by concerns that quality at nursing homes was declining as large chains were acquired by private investment groups.
articles.abstract: Congressional hearings were prompted in part by concerns that quality at nursing homes was declining as large chains were acquired by private investment groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15  Lawmakers in two hearings on Thursday proposed ways to force nursing homes to provide more details about ownership and to hold those owners more accountable when problems emerge.

articles.headline: As Bank Profits Grew, Warning Signs Went Unheeded
articles.snippet: There were signs that banks were either lying about their results or were taking large risks that were not fully disclosed, but investors were oblivious.
articles.abstract: There were signs that banks were either lying about their results or were taking large risks that were not fully disclosed, but investors were oblivious.
articles.lead_paragraph: We should have known something was strange. The banks were doing a lot better than they should have been doing.

articles.headline: Tokyo Seeking a Top Niche in Global Finance
articles.snippet: As Japan’s focus on manufacturing wanes, planners are trying to reverse engineer another source of the United States’ economic strength: Wall Street.
articles.abstract: As Japan’s focus on manufacturing wanes, planners are trying to reverse engineer another source of the United States’ economic strength: Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Nov. 15 — Years ago, Japan rose to economic prominence by taking apart American products like cars and television sets to learn how to make them better.

articles.headline: China Stand on Imports Upsets U.S.
articles.snippet: A recent pattern in which China issues regulations aimed at favoring Chinese industries over foreign competitors has raised concerns among U.S. officials.
articles.abstract: A recent pattern in which China issues regulations aimed at favoring Chinese industries over foreign competitors has raised concerns among U.S. officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 — Few American industries have had more success in selling goods to China than makers of medical devices like X-rays, pacemakers and patient monitors. Which is why a recent Chinese decree was so troubling.

articles.headline: Clinton’s in Thick of Barbed Democratic Debate
articles.snippet: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton warned her rivals that they risked playing into the hands of Republicans.
articles.abstract: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton warned her rivals that they risked playing into the hands of Republicans.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton shifted to a much more assertive tone in a debate Thursday night by going directly after her opponents, issuing a stern warning that Democrats should stop “throwing mud” and adopting tactics “right out of the Republican playbook.”
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Jeff Zeleny
